bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 1 (Tuesday, January 3, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. KING of Iowa:H.R. 177.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article III, Section 2, Clause 1Article I, Section 8, Clause 9[Page H51]

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on the Constitution and Civil Justice.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

summary.text:
This bill bars the Supreme Court from citing for the purpose of precedence [sic] in all future cases the following Supreme Court decisions concerning the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act:

  • National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius,
  • King v. Burwell, and
  • Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores Inc.

bill.title: To bar Supreme Court decisions in certain Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act cases from citation.

item.title: To bar Supreme Court decisions in certain Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act cases from citation.
To bar Supreme Court decisions in certain Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act cases from citation.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on the Constitution and Civil Justice.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
